messageBody:
Quoting Emily Bache <emily.bache@...>:

> > From: Shane Celis <shane@...>
> > Many times over JUnit seems to be employed for
> > functional/acceptance/integration testing (usually somewhat
> > awkwardly).
> > Are there any testing approaches or frameworks that can be
> > suggested for
> > this sort of testing? Because many of the methodologies
> > suggested for
> > unit testing aren't applicable to this sort of testing. Have
> > the xUnit
> > people, or anyone else for that matter, addressed this problem
> space?
>
> Hi,
>
> I am currently co-writing a practitioners report submission for the
> XP2002
> conference about our[*] experiences with acceptance testing. We've got
> a
> testing framework that's not based on JUnit at all, and we think it's
> working very well.
>
> We force the application to operate in batch mode while we acceptance
> test
> it, provide input from file/standard input redirects, and collect all
> output
> as text files. We then have the full power of unix text processing
> commands
> (ie diff) to analyse and compare the output to previous runs. Basically,
> if
> the output is different, the test fails.
<snip />

My last recommendation to IBM's e-commerce organization, before I left, was to
implement something similar for their system. They have been struggling with
automating test cases because they have focussed on automating tests through
the browser interface, when usually they want to test the application's
business behavior. I didn't think about distributing the test execution at the
time, so that's quite neat.

Although not everyone agrees that test-oriented design tends to lead to better
design overall, I think that refactoring a system to allow this text-based,
batch operation has a strong chance of resulting in a more highly change-
resistant design.

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
